error.signature: SSL: error:0A000086:SSL routines::certificate verify failed (unable to get local issuer certificate)
error.regex: unable to get local issuer certificate|incomplete certificate chain|chain.*incomplete|verify error:num=2[01]|missing intermediate

verdict.summary: The TLS server presents a leaf certificate without the required intermediate CA certificates. Clients cannot build a chain of trust to a root CA and reject the connection. This is a server-side configuration issue.

dead_ends.action: Disable certificate verification on the client to bypass the error
dead_ends.why_fails: Disabling verification (e.g., curl -k, verify=False) removes all TLS security guarantees and opens the connection to man-in-the-middle attacks. It does not fix the server misconfiguration.

dead_ends.action: Install the leaf certificate directly into the client trust store
dead_ends.why_fails: Pinning the leaf certificate works temporarily but breaks when the certificate is renewed. Every client must be manually updated, which does not scale.

workarounds.action: Configure the server to send the full certificate chain including intermediate CA certificates
workarounds.how:
1. Identify the leaf certificate issuer: openssl x509 -in cert.pem -noout -issuer
2. Download the intermediate CA certificate from the CA's repository
3. Concatenate: cat cert.pem intermediate.pem > fullchain.pem
4. Configure the server to use fullchain.pem as the certificate file
5. Verify: openssl s_client -connect host:443 -showcerts | grep 'Certificate chain'
6. Confirm the chain is complete: openssl verify -CAfile /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt fullchain.pem

workarounds.action: Use an ACME client like certbot that automatically provides the full chain
workarounds.how:
1. Install certbot: apt install certbot
2. Obtain a certificate: certbot certonly --standalone -d example.com
3. Use the fullchain.pem file (not cert.pem) in your server configuration
4. Certbot places the full chain at /etc/letsencrypt/live/example.com/fullchain.pem
5. Verify: openssl s_client -connect example.com:443 -showcerts

leads_to.condition: when the client cannot verify the chain and reports a generic verification failure

preceded_by.condition: when renewing an expired certificate but forgetting to include the intermediate in the new bundle

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Incomplete chain means intermediates are missing but a valid CA-signed cert exists; self-signed means the certificate was not issued by any recognized CA at all
